P.title: Will the US government increase funding for nuclear safety research by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US government has officially increased funding for nuclear safety research compared to the funding levels of 2024. The increase must be documented in an official budget proposal or appropriations bill passed by Congress. The increase must be at least 10% above the 2024 funding level for nuclear safety research as defined by the Department of Energy and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Any funding increases that are temporary, one-time allocations, or related to specific projects without ongoing commitment do not count towards this resolution.

Q.title: Will there be a major public safety incident related to nuclear facilities in the US before 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, any of the following occurs: (1) a significant nuclear incident classified as a Level 3 or higher on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES) occurs at a nuclear facility in the US, resulting in public exposure to radiation or a public safety alert; (2) a major security breach at a nuclear facility that leads to a credible threat to public safety, as reported by a reputable news source (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post); (3) an event causing a substantial evacuation or emergency response related to a nuclear facility, officially recognized by government agencies such as the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). Minor incidents or routine safety drills do not count towards this resolution.

P_given_Q.title: Conditional on a major public safety incident related to nuclear facilities occurring in the US before 2025, will the US government increase funding for nuclear safety research by 2025?
P_given_Q.body:

The increase must be at least 10% above the 2024 funding level for nuclear safety research as defined by the Department of Energy and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Any funding increases that are temporary, one-time allocations, or related to specific projects without ongoing commitment do not count towards this resolution.

Criterion for condition: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, any of the following occurs: (1) a significant nuclear incident classified as a Level 3 or higher on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES) occurs at a nuclear facility in the US, resulting in public exposure to radiation or a public safety alert; (2) a major security breach at a nuclear facility that leads to a credible threat to public safety, as reported by a reputable news source (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post); (3) an event causing a substantial evacuation or emergency response related to a nuclear facility, officially recognized by government agencies such as the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). Minor incidents or routine safety drills do not count towards this resolution.

P_given_not_Q.title: Given there is no major public safety incident related to nuclear facilities in the US before 2025, will the US government increase funding for nuclear safety research by 2025?
P_given_not_Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the US government has officially increased funding for nuclear safety research compared to the funding levels of 2024. The increase must be at least 10% above the 2024 funding level for nuclear safety research as defined by the Department of Energy and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Any funding increases that are temporary, one-time allocations, or related to specific projects without ongoing commitment do not count towards this resolution.

Minor incidents or routine safety drills do not count.

P.title: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the leader in global digital governance based on the following criteria: 
- South Korea must have implemented comprehensive digital governance policies that are adopted and followed by at least 75% of its population, as verified by government reports and independent surveys. 
- South Korea must hold a prominent position in international digital governance forums, such as the OECD and G20, where it leads discussions and initiatives on digital policy, cybersecurity, and data privacy. 
- The country must be acknowledged in at least three reputable international reports or rankings (e.g., by the World Economic Forum, UN, or similar organizations) as the top nation in digital governance practices. 
- Significant collaborations or partnerships with at least three other countries in establishing global digital standards must be in place, with documented agreements and initiatives. 
In the absence of clear consensus, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will South Korea host a major international summit on digital governance by 2026?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, South Korea has officially hosted a major international summit focused on digital governance. The summit must include participation from at least 10 countries and involve discussions on key topics such as data privacy, cybersecurity, and international regulations on digital platforms. The event must be confirmed by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times) and must not be a smaller regional meeting or a virtual conference. In the case of multiple summits, only the first one that meets these criteria will be considered for resolution.

P_given_Q.title: Given that South Korea hosts a major international summit on digital governance by 2026, will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?
P_given_Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the leader in global digital governance based on the following criteria: 
- South Korea must have implemented comprehensive digital governance policies that are adopted and followed by at least 75% of its population, as verified by government reports and independent surveys. 
- South Korea must hold a prominent position in international digital governance forums, such as the OECD and G20, where it leads discussions and initiatives on digital policy, cybersecurity, and data privacy. 
- The country must be acknowledged in at least three reputable international reports or rankings (e.g., by the World Economic Forum, UN, or similar organizations) as the top nation in digital governance practices. 
- Significant collaborations or partnerships with at least three other countries in establishing global digital standards must be in place, with documented agreements and initiatives. 

This resolution is contingent upon the prior condition being met: the question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, South Korea has officially hosted a major international summit focused on digital governance, which must include participation from at least 10 countries and involve discussions on key topics such as data privacy, cybersecurity, and international regulations on digital platforms. The event must be confirmed by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times) and must not be a smaller regional meeting or a virtual conference. In the case of multiple summits, only the first one that meets these criteria will be considered for resolution.

P_given_not_Q.title: Conditional on South Korea not hosting a major international summit on digital governance by 2026, will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?
P_given_not_Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the leader in global digital governance based on the following criteria:

- Significant collaborations or partnerships with at least three other countries in establishing global digital standards must be in place, with documented agreements and initiatives. 
In the absence of clear consensus, the question will resolve as No.

Resolution criteria for the condition: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, South Korea has not officially hosted a major international summit focused on digital governance, which must not include participation from at least 10 countries and must not involve discussions on key topics such as data privacy, cybersecurity, and international regulations on digital platforms. The event must not be confirmed by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times) and must be a smaller regional meeting or a virtual conference. In the case of multiple summits, only the first one that does not meet these criteria will be considered for resolution.

P.title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge inspire similar commitments in the manufacturing industry by 2032?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, at least three major manufacturing companies publicly announce and commit to carbon negative pledges that are inspired by Microsoft's carbon negative initiative. The pledges must include specific targets for carbon reduction and timelines that are clearly defined. The announcements must be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must be verifiable through official corporate communications or sustainability reports. A commitment must include measurable actions and not just intentions or vague statements. If a company retracts its commitment or fails to implement its pledge within the specified timeline, it will not count towards the resolution of this question.

Q.title: Will governmental policies be enacted to support corporate carbon negative efforts by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, any government (federal, state, or local) enacts policies specifically designed to support corporate efforts to achieve carbon negativity. These policies must include measurable incentives such as tax breaks, grants, or subsidies aimed at reducing carbon emissions beyond neutrality. The policies must be publicly documented and verifiable through official government publications or announcements. Additionally, credible reports from at least two major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the enactment of such policies will also suffice. Policies that are merely proposals or in draft form will not count towards resolution.

P_given_Q.title: Given that governmental policies are enacted to support corporate carbon negative efforts by 2025, will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge inspire similar commitments in the manufacturing industry by 2032?
P_given_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, at least three major manufacturing companies publicly announce and commit to carbon negative pledges that are inspired by Microsoft's carbon negative initiative, provided that these commitments occur after the enactment of supportive governmental policies by December 31, 2025. The pledges must include specific targets for carbon reduction and timelines that are clearly defined. The announcements must be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must be verifiable through official corporate communications or sustainability reports. A commitment must include measurable actions and not just intentions or vague statements. If a company retracts its commitment or fails to implement its pledge within the specified timeline, it will not count towards the resolution of this question.

P_given_not_Q.title: Given that no governmental policies will be enacted to support corporate carbon negative efforts by 2025, will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge inspire similar commitments in the manufacturing industry by 2032?
P_given_not_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, at least three major manufacturing companies publicly announce and commit to carbon negative pledges that are inspired by Microsoft's carbon negative initiative, provided that no government (federal, state, or local) enacts policies specifically designed to support corporate efforts to achieve carbon negativity by December 31, 2025. The pledges must include specific targets for carbon reduction and timelines that are clearly defined. The announcements must be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must be verifiable through official corporate communications or sustainability reports. A commitment must include measurable actions and not just intentions or vague statements. If a company retracts its commitment or fails to implement its pledge within the specified timeline, it will not count towards the resolution of this question.

P.title: Will India collaborate with another country on a major quantum computing project by 2027?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, India has officially entered into a collaborative agreement with another country on a major quantum computing project. A 'major quantum computing project' is defined as a project with a budget exceeding $50 million and involving significant research and development efforts in quantum technologies. The collaboration must be publicly announced by the governments or relevant agencies of both India and the collaborating country. Credible reports from at least three major news organizations (such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, etc.) confirming the collaboration will also suffice for resolution. If the project is canceled or significantly downsized, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will India produce a functional quantum computer that surpasses 100 qubits by 2028?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, India has produced a functional quantum computer that is capable of operating with more than 100 qubits. The quantum computer must be publicly demonstrated to perform a quantum algorithm that showcases its capabilities, such as quantum supremacy or a significant computational advantage over classical computers. The demonstration must be reported by at least two reputable sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must be verified by independent experts in the field of quantum computing. The definition of 'functional' means that the quantum computer can reliably manipulate and measure qubits without significant errors that would undermine its performance.

P_given_Q.title: Conditional on India producing a functional quantum computer that surpasses 100 qubits by 2028, will India collaborate with another country on a major quantum computing project by 2027?
P_given_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, India has officially entered into a collaborative agreement with another country on a major quantum computing project, defined as a project with a budget exceeding $50 million and involving significant research and development efforts in quantum technologies. The collaboration must be publicly announced by the governments or relevant agencies of both India and the collaborating country. Credible reports from at least three major news organizations (such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, etc.) confirming the collaboration will also suffice for resolution. If the project is canceled or significantly downsized, the question will resolve as No. The first condition is that by December 31, 2028, India has produced a functional quantum computer capable of operating with more than 100 qubits, publicly demonstrated to perform a quantum algorithm showcasing its capabilities, and verified by independent experts.

P_given_not_Q.title: Conditional on India not producing a functional quantum computer that surpasses 100 qubits by 2028, will India collaborate with another country on a major quantum computing project by 2027?
P_given_not_Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, India has not produced a functional quantum computer that is capable of operating with more than 100 qubits, meaning it must not be publicly demonstrated to perform a quantum algorithm that showcases its capabilities, such as quantum supremacy or a significant computational advantage over classical computers. The demonstration must not be reported by at least two reputable sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must not be verified by independent experts in the field of quantum computing. Furthermore, by December 31, 2027, India must have officially entered into a collaborative agreement with another country on a major quantum computing project, defined as a project with a budget exceeding $50 million and involving significant research and development efforts in quantum technologies. The collaboration must be publicly announced by the governments or relevant agencies of both India and the collaborating country, with credible reports from at least three major news organizations confirming the collaboration. If the project is canceled or significantly downsized, the question will resolve as No.

A 'major quantum computing project' is defined as a project with a budget exceeding $50 million and involving significant research and development efforts in quantum technologies. The collaboration must be publicly announced by the governments or relevant agencies of both India and the collaborating country. Credible reports from at least three major news organizations (such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, etc.) confirming the collaboration will also suffice for resolution. P.title: Will public opinion in EU countries support nuclear energy as a solution to climate change by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a majority of public opinion polls conducted in EU countries indicate that at least 50% of respondents support the use of nuclear energy as a solution to climate change. The polls must be conducted by reputable polling organizations and published in recognized media outlets. The question of support for nuclear energy must be clearly defined in the polls as relating to its role in addressing climate change, specifically. If there is a significant variance in support across different countries, the resolution will still be based on the overall majority across the EU. Additionally, support must be consistent over at least three separate polls conducted within the last year leading up to the resolution date.

Q.title: Will the European Union establish a centralized nuclear waste storage facility by 2035?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, the European Union has officially established a centralized nuclear waste storage facility that is operational and accepting nuclear waste from member states. The facility must be recognized and regulated by the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) and comply with all relevant EU safety and environmental regulations. Confirmation of the establishment must come from an official EU announcement or reputable news sources (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). If the facility is partially operational or limited to specific member states, it must be intended for full EU-wide operation to resolve as Yes. Temporary or trial facilities do not count towards this question's resolution.

P_given_Q.title: Conditional on the European Union establishing a centralized nuclear waste storage facility by 2035, will public opinion in EU countries support nuclear energy as a solution to climate change by 2030?
P_given_Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, the European Union has officially established a centralized nuclear waste storage facility that is operational and accepting nuclear waste from member states, recognized and regulated by the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM), and compliant with all relevant EU safety and environmental regulations. Confirmation of establishment must come from an official EU announcement or reputable news sources (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). If the facility is partially operational or limited to specific member states, it must be intended for full EU-wide operation to resolve as Yes. Temporary or trial facilities do not count towards this question's resolution. 

Additionally, this question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a majority of public opinion polls conducted in EU countries indicate that at least 50% of respondents support the use of nuclear energy as a solution to climate change. The polls must be conducted by reputable polling organizations and published in recognized media outlets. The question of support for nuclear energy must be clearly defined in the polls as relating to its role in addressing climate change, specifically. If there is a significant variance in support across different countries, the resolution will still be based on the overall majority across the EU. Additionally, support must be consistent over at least three separate polls conducted within the last year leading up to the resolution date.

P_given_not_Q.title: Conditional on the European Union not establishing a centralized nuclear waste storage facility by 2035, will public opinion in EU countries support nuclear energy as a solution to climate change by 2030?
P_given_not_Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a majority of public opinion polls conducted in EU countries indicate that at least 50% of respondents support the use of nuclear energy as a solution to climate change. The polls must be conducted by reputable polling organizations and published in recognized media outlets. The question of support for nuclear energy must be clearly defined in the polls as relating to its role in addressing climate change, specifically. If there is a significant variance in support across different countries, the resolution will still be based on the overall majority across the EU. Additionally, support must be consistent over at least three separate polls conducted within the last year leading up to the resolution date.

Criterion for condition: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, the European Union has not officially established a centralized nuclear waste storage facility that is operational and accepting nuclear waste from member states. The facility must not be recognized and regulated by the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) and must not comply with all relevant EU safety and environmental regulations. Confirmation of the establishment must not come from an official EU announcement or reputable news sources (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post).
